Trump Picks New Director Of National Intelligence Amid Claims Of Complete Restructuring "... no truth to this idea ..." by Charles Campbell January 5, 2017 at 6:08pm Share on Facebook Share Tweet Email Email Print   
President-elect Donald Trump named U.S. Senator Dan Coats as his director of national intelligence Thursday, fueling speculation the incoming administration will seek to completely reform the nation’s top intelligence agencies. 
The news comes after a senior Trump transition official confirmed a Wednesday report by the Wall Street Journal which hinted that the new administration was taking ideas regarding reform seriously. 
However, incoming White House Press Secretary Sean Spicer has denied those allegations, telling reporters Thursday they were “100 percent false.”   Trump Announces Surprise Meeting With A Longtime Nemesis 
“These reports are false. All transition activities are for information gathering purposes, and all discussions are tentative,” Spicer said. 
“I want to reiterate, there is no truth to this idea of restructuring the intelligence community infrastructure. It is 100 percent false,” he added. 
Sources familair with the planning team told the Wall Street Journal that Trump believes the Office of the Director of National Intelligence has become “bloated and politicized.”   
Coates, who will soon be serving as the director of national intelligence, just finished a six-year term in the U.S. Senate. Before that, he was the U.S. ambassador to Germany for President George W. Bush. 
U.S. officials familiar with national intelligence claim Coates is “very well respected on both sides of the aisle.” And a Democratic official said the former senator was a “very reasonable guy.” 
Senate Intelligence Chairman Richard Burr told reporters that Coates is an “excellent choice.” 
“Dan’s got the experience, he’s got the leadership skills having been an ambassador and I think his time on the committee has served him to understand what that role entails,” Burr said.
